* Hugh Winkler <hughw@...> [2008-04-15 00:45]:
> The questionable part might overloading PUT to mean COPY, but
> if you believe PUT has the flexibility to interpret the entity
> and do something creative that ends up with a resource being
> available at that URI, then no problem. This is like the PATCH
> discussion. I think most people thought it was wrong to PUT a
> special differences document -- but I was unconvinced.

The reason to have PATCH is that if the only way to patch a
resource is to PUT the patch, then clients have no way to *store*
patch documents (ie. use PUT for PUT semantics).

That might not be a concern in *your* web app, since yours might
be able to accept only a limited range of media types in PUT
requests, so the question of disambiguating patching from storing
might not come up. But in the general case it is an issue.

> It's wrong to suppose that any agent is going to PUT these
> documents to some unsuspecting server and something bad will
> happen. I'm not going to let my agent PUT these anywhere I
> haven't been instructed to by some hypertext I received
> earlier, or by reading the documentation.

If S3 is the only place that demands as well as understands such
requests, you are not engineering for serendipity.

Also, keep intermediaries in mind.
